tweet: NEWS: Health Subcommittee announces legislative hearing to consider Chairman @FrankPallone's bill to respond to the national youth tobacco epidemic.
NEWS: Health Subcommittee announces details for field hearing in Chicago on the public health threat of gun violence and the need to conduct research into this epidemic.

Yesterday, the Environment & Climate Change Subcommittee favorably reported 15 bills to the full Committee, including bills that ban asbestos and address PFAS contamination. WATCH @RepDebDingell discuss the importance of taking action. pic.twitter.com/w83aLvrnDf
WATCH LIVE: Communications & Technology Subcommittee legislative hearing on supply chain security and spectrum →

News: Hearing scheduled on corporate responsibility online, consumer protection & the pros and cons of Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act. https://energycommerce.house.gov/newsroom/press-releases/hearing-scheduled-on-corporate-responsibility-online-consumer-protection-the …
Update: HR 2699 was favorably reported to the full Committee by a voice vote.

The final bill is HR 2699, the Nuclear Waste Policy Amendments Act of 2019, introduced by @RepMcNerney and @RepShimkus. The bipartisan bill amends the Nuclear Waste Policy Act to update the Department of Energy’s ability to manage nuclear waste. pic.twitter.com/uMEazez0QV
Update: HR 2638 was favorably reported to the full Committee by a voice vote.

Now up for debate is HR 2638, introduced by @RepFletcher. This bill directs the @EPA Administrator to issue guidance to minimize the use of foam and other firefighting materials containing PFAS and the health risk from PFAS exposure for firefighters and other first responders. pic.twitter.com/0tmi1ad8UR
Update: HR 2626 was favorably reported to the full Committee by a voice vote.

HR 2626, the PFAS Accountability Act of 2019, introduced by @RepFredUpton, amends the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (CERCLA) to require cleanups at federal facilities to meet state limits for PFAS. pic.twitter.com/MTogaNE80X
Update: HR 2608 was favorably reported to the full Committee by a voice vote.

Next up: HR 2608, the PFAS Testing Act of 2019. It was introduced by @RepSeanMaloney and requires comprehensive health testing of all PFAS under the Toxic Substances Control Act and reports of PFAS impacts from all manufacturers and processors. pic.twitter.com/pnrXMW51OW
Update: HR 2605 was favorably reported to the full Committee by a voice vote.

Coming up is HR 2605, the PROTECT Act of 2019, introduced by @RepHaleyStevens. This bill directs @EPA to issue a final rule adding a full group of toxic PFAS chemicals to the list of hazardous air pollutants of the Clean Air Act. pic.twitter.com/r8qstFx2tt
Update: HR 2600 was favorably reported to the full Committee by a voice vote.

HR 2600, the Toxic PFAS Control Act, introduced by @RepDean, amends the Toxic Substances Control Act to prohibit the manufacture or processing of any new PFAS chemical substance as a “significant new use.” pic.twitter.com/tCcuxL3C7H
Update: HR 2596 was favorably reported to the full Committee by a voice vote.

Now up for debate is HR 2596, the Protecting Communities from New PFAS Act, introduced by @RepAnnieKuster. It requires that any PFAS substance for which a manufacturing and processing notice is submitted must be deemed to present an “unreasonable risk.” pic.twitter.com/2izfn6Gxrc
Update: HR 2591 was favorably reported to the full Committee by a voice vote.

Next up: HR 2591, the PFAS Waste Incineration Ban Act of 2019, introduced by @RepRoKhanna. This bill amends the Solid Waste Disposal Act to prohibit the burning of fire-fighting foam containing per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances. pic.twitter.com/EhzPMMl7kY
Update: HR 2577 was favorably reported to the full Committee by a voice vote.

HR 2577, the PFAS Right-To-Know Act, introduced by @repdelgado, amends the Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know Act of 1986 to include per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances on the Toxics Release Inventory. pic.twitter.com/ZHrfStnuUh
Update: HR 2533 was favorably reported to the full Committee by a voice vote.

HR 2533, the Providing Financial Assistance for Safe Drinking Water Act, introduced by Chairman @FrankPallone, requires @EPA to establish a grant program to help PFAS-affected communities filter the toxic chemicals out of their water systems. pic.twitter.com/vKgZRn943P
Update: HR 2570 was favorably reported to the full Committee by a voice vote.

Coming up for debate is HR 2570, the PFAS User Fee Act of 2019. Introduced by @RepHarley, this bill requires that polluters pay ongoing treatment costs for water contaminated with PFAS. pic.twitter.com/nVfPwb0L3Y
Update: HR 2566 was favorably reported to the full Committee by a voice vote.

Now up is HR 2566, introduced by @RepDarrenSoto. The bill would require the @EPA Administrator to update the Safer Choice Standard to include a Safer Choice label for pots, pans and cooking utensils that do not contain PFAS. pic.twitter.com/zHwectuNTb
Update: HR 2377 was favorably reported to the full Committee by a voice vote.

Up next: HR 2377, the Protect Drinking Water from PFAS Act of 2019. Introduced by @CongBoyle and @RepBrianFitz, this bipartisan bill requires the @EPA Administrator publish a maximum contaminant level goal and circulate a national drinking water standard within two years. pic.twitter.com/vGrXyMQbzI
Update: HR 535 was favorably reported to the full Committee by a voice vote.

HR 535, the bipartisan PFAS Action Act of 2019, introduced by @RepDebDingell and @RepFredUpton, would require the @EPA Administrator to designate all per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances as hazardous under the Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (CERCLA). pic.twitter.com/Bj4yfMB0fe
Update: HR 1603 was favorably reported to the full Committee by a voice vote.

First up is HR 1603, the Alan Reinstein #BanAsbestosNow Act, introduced by @RepBonamici, Chairman @Frankpallone & @RepSlotkin. It would completely ban the production, use and importation of asbestos, which kills 40,000 Americans each year. pic.twitter.com/hgdgf43G8P

At a Committee oversight hearing today on the growing public health crisis involving e-cigarettes, the @FDACommissioner admitted that it was slow to act. Chairman @FrankPallone warned the Administration about the impacts of inaction two years ago, and stressed that again today. pic.twitter.com/cRDmLFNI6a

It’s time to turn back the clock on rising prescription drug prices. 

It’s time to negotiate a better deal for all Americans.

It’s time for the #LowerDrugCosts Now Act. pic.twitter.com/VNY8bBTgFo

Today Committee leaders released a new @GAO report that confirms their concerns that cybersecurity risks to our electric grid are significant and growing. They pledged to act in a bipartisan fashion to ensure these risks do not materialize. https://energycommerce.house.gov/newsroom/press-releases/committee-releases-gao-report-warning-of-cybersecurity-risks-facing-us …

Three in ten adults reported not taking their medicines as prescribed at some point in the past year because of the cost. The #LowerDrugCosts Now Act provides some much needed relief to seniors by capping drug costs. pic.twitter.com/KZZhkwoCu3

Your first thought after being diagnosed with cancer shouldn’t be: “Can I afford treatment?” But this is the sad reality for so many Americans. That’s got to change. The #LowerDrugCosts Now Act works to do just that. pic.twitter.com/ObNGc7Ro1W

Bottom line: People in other countries shouldn’t be paying 10 times less on their prescription drugs than people here in the U.S.  It’s time we negotiate a better deal for all Americans. #RT if you agree. #LowerDrugCosts pic.twitter.com/KNOYRcNdBA
